intro: Ocimum ciliare, commonly known as Mexican basil, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Central America and parts of the Caribbean. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, oval-shaped leaves with a serrated margin. Its small, tubular flowers are usually violet or purple, arranged in whorled clusters at the leaf axils. Ocimum ciliare is valued for its fragrant leaves, which are used in culinary and medicinal applications.
